subject: user-manager: change default nslcd cert path
commitMessage:
user-manager: change default nslcd cert path

This change also includes rpm-postinst script to move
nslcd ssl certs if they are exists.

Make user manager to configure nslcd with /etc/ssl/certs
directory when secure LDAP is enabled. Base OpenBMC repo
doesn't contain recipes that ships such certificates.

This change required as a part of privilege separation work:
   https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/issues/3383

This change should be merged after individual repo change:
   https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-user-manager/+/41429

Signed-off-by: Anton D. Kachalov <gmouse@google.com>
Change-Id: Ie8db92acfe5da62d7b75afd5f4f0b68da3ea31af

Why?  Just fix the env file here.  You haven't actually solved the mess of dependencies I complained about in phosphor-user-manager/41429.

(I think this is also the same thing Jayanth is pointing out).
Not clear. Where I have to fix the path? The env file is being shipped from the phosphor-certificate repo within previous change in the chain and it's deps.

> The env file is being shipped from the phosphor-certificate repo within previous change in the chain and it's deps.

This is my problem.  Do one thing and do it well.  Don't do multiple things.

You have path change depending on recipe changes in openbmc depending on this change depending on delivering services files here depending on recipe changes in openbmc.  Stop the madness.

Make 1 change in user-manager and 1 change in openbmc for the feature of "I am going to rename the path where certificates go".  Don't make this mess of interdependent commits that nobody can keep track of and are going to be merged wrongly.

This particular change is only catching up changes in two underlying individual repos with path's change. We need to make those changes to be merged and bumped at once. I don't know better way of syncing up incompatible changes between repos.

> I don't know better way of syncing up incompatible changes between repos.

I don't know how many times I can say it:

Make 1 change in user-manager and 1 change in openbmc for the feature of "I am going to rename the path where certificates go".  Don't make this mess of interdependent commits that nobody can keep track of and are going to be merged wrongly.

Renaming the path is tangential to the "delivering stuff in the repo".  Don't conflate them.  It is nice you discovered this while doing the other work but that doesn't mean you need to tangle it all up into the same mess of commits.
Have splitted the change. Now changes to cert-manager ships non-nslcd related changes from the repo leaving nslcd-related to ship from user-manager repo.
nslcd path is initialized in openbmc/meta-phosphor/recipes-phosphor/certificate/phosphor-nslcd-cert-config/env.  env config is used by phosphor-certificate-manger to manage certificate.
It was modified in previous change in the chain. Env file is being distributed right from the phosphor-certificate repo.
Looks like the 'nobranch' got in here from an earlier commit.  We'll want to make sure that doesn't get merged.
This wouldn't merge. The commit revision and "nobranch=1" required to pass the CI tests.

Why are we leaving the files in the old location?

Is there a requirement to allow downgrade to the prior layout.

Can we have these scripts do the revert on some arg?

Is there a design doc with a description of what is being done?

The other change in user-manager repo has moved files to the new unified location.

I don't think we have any reqs for downgrades. The only reliable option for downgrades of incompatible versions is to wipe non-sensitive files (e.g. not whitelisted). The nslcd config is being re-created by user-manager.

There much more effort to do the revert of configs and I'm unsure that we support that in the past. The target's postinst scripts weren't used before for any kind of live data migration. I can recall only one a kind of migration (only upgrade) within a hardcoded chunks of code in bmcweb (moving certs from one location to another), but it doesn't seem to be a proper way.

I introduced the proposal of privilege separation work that includes migration approach in both mailing list and on the past OBMC Security Workgroup meeting:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1EI-HfPb_NMp9GD0fY6-XCpnKAX6-ZsdpDEsmiX5d6fc/edit?usp=sharing

Please use the design template to document this design with a gerrit review.

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/designs/design-template.md

Especially the impacts to the existing codebase and migration plans.
Do you need nobranch ?
It's required for CI to pass the tests. Once the corresponding change will be merged, this will be updated too and "nobranch" will be removed.
Ok I thought for a bit it had merged.
Done
This snippet will execute the condition every IPL
Not sure, why it should run every boot? Once the postinst script is being executed, the file would be removed.

Actually this code will error if the directory exists but no certs are in the subdirectory.  The if doesn't match the mv.

And why is the config only removed if the grep is true. What other content can it have?  What would have previously set the line in question?

The "if"-statement can check for file presence under /etc/nslcd/certs. I will change it.

If the config has "tls_cert" set, then we need to re-generate the config with new path. Otherwise, we have nslcd without TLS.

PS. The part with postinst in Yocto is a bit unreliable -- if the postinst script fails, it will be removed in either way: on failure or success.

Also if these certificates are always customized in the system and not deployed can we move them to /var/lib/_program_ ?   This allows us to avoid the overlays for etc (in the UBI and mmc today, and I hope static in the future).

I'm not 100% sure that certificates couldn't be pre-deployed.
Anyway, this is going to be a significant change that should be made/tested separately (volatile Vs non-volatile storage, hardcoded paths at least in bmcweb).
It has dependencies to other user-manager and certificate-manager changes.

Ok.   Was hoping to make two changes at once but I'm okay if we aren't sure.

Presumably the old oath will not be present in the new image if it was always predeployed.

Should these files and directories be chown to the user and explicit permission set
?   Should the mkdir be part of the base image ?

I was asked explicitly to make the changes separately.

This change is not introducing the permissions' changes while the user-manager is still running under the root.

The certificate-manager do the mkdir by itself, but we have to move existing certs beforehand, thus, have to create the directory first. Before this change, the directory /etc/ssl/certs is empty too. Subdirs are not a part of the image.
Any reason for that?

> Any reason for that?

Sorry, could you please elaborate on the question?
Is there a reason that the file system doesn't have the full directory path installed and the mkdir is done at runtime?   Ie why are subdirs not a part of the image.

That's a good question 😊
Let's add it at build time.
